repnme.cdata!: World Bank projects in private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ukraine's European course, declared
            by the supreme state power and supported by society,
            determines the nature of market reforms carried out by the
            Ukrainian Government. This line of reforms is actively
            supported by the World Bank, with its most important
            projects aimed at building up the private sector in Ukraine.
            In 1996 and 1998, the enterprise development adjustment
            loans (EDAL) I and II were implemented in two stages. In
            2002, the World Bank approved granting a loan to Ukraine for
            the private sector development project. This project is a
            systemic (adjustment) type, being oriented not only to the
            extensive development of private enterprises, but also to
            increasing the efficiency and profitability of production,
            and the manufacture of competitive products. The project
            objective is also to ensure that privatized enterprises
            themselves, after acquiring know-how and work experience
            under the conditions of new economic realities, become
            experts and leaders of enterprise restructuring, supporters,
            and implementers of market ideas in the regions.
            Introduction of the latest models of information and
            communication technologies (ICT) can considerably increase
            the efficiency and expeditiousness of decisions approval,
            stimulate the development of the private sector, and
            strengthen civil society in Ukraine. In order to attain
            these goals, a credit agreement on financing the project
            Ukraine: e-development was signed in 2003 between the World
            Bank and the Ukrainian Government. The activities envisaged
            by the project have positive prospects for consolidating
            administrative reform.

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Enterprise Development Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Development Adjustment
            Loan (EDAL) Project's outcome is rated as satisfactory.
            The early 1990s were tumultuous years in Ukraine when the
            country was newly independent. Managing independence and
            balancing national identity with the relationship with
            Russia and other competing issues made it difficult for the
            Government to focus entirely on the implementation. The
            experience of the EDAL showed that in transition economies
            the results from policy reforms are far enhanced if they are
            accompanied by technical assistance (TA). The TA is
            instrumental in training key players in how to operate in
            the new environment. The TA component also allowed for low
            cost experimentation, particularly with sensitive issues
            like enterprise bankruptcy. In the TA component the
            Government official who had championed the first and second
            EDAL loans was removed from his position as head of the
            State Property Fund. This created a situation in which there
            was no accountability for the program. The Government
            recommended that future projects involve a detailed action
            plan agreed between the Bank and the relevant implementing
            state agencies on the steps to be taken for the actual
            implementation of the agreed reforms. Far greater
            involvement from the Bank's Resident Office would have
            been most helpful particularly in the early stages of the
            project. The Government noted it was important to develop a
            joint strategy for reform and building consensus with all
            key players.

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Enterprise Development Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Enterprise
            Development Adjustment Loan Project is to support the
            government's trade and price liberalization,
            privatization, capital markets development and
            post-privatization restructuring programs. Other objectives
            are to: 1) provide foreign exchange for the purchase of
            critical imports; and 2) support the development of the
            foreign exchange markets. The components of the project will
            be: 1) balance of payments support for policy reforms; and
            2) technical assistance for post-privatization
            restructuring. The policy reforms will include: 1)
            elimination of trade barriers and price restrictions on
            imports and exports; 2) elimination of domestic price
            controls; 3) implementation of mass privatization of 5,000
            medium and large scale enterprises; 4) completion of the
            small scale privatization program; 5) resolution of several
            important methodological obstacles to rapid implementation
            of the privatization program; 6) extension of the
            privatization program to include additional large
            enterprises for case-by-case privatization; 7) creation of a
            Securities and Stock Markets Commission to oversee and
            regulate capital markets; 8) creation of self-regulatory
            organizations for intermediaries in the capital markets; and
            9) legislation governing stock exchanges and
            over-the-counter markets, dealers and brokers, independent
            registrars and depositories, self-regulatory organizations
            of market participants, and rules governing investor protection.

docna.cdata!:
Ukraine - Enterprise Development Adjustment
            Loan Project
